Childe Esquire.

DIV1.P: A SHORT COMPENDIUM OF The New and much Enlarged SEA-BOOK, OR Pilots Sea-Mirror: CONTAINING The Distances and Thwart Courses of the Eastern, Northern, and Western NAVIGATION.

P.HI: Newly Enlarged and amended, by several Experienced NAVIGATORS.

DIV1.P: And now for the Benefit and Encouragement of our SEA-MEN Translated into ENGLISH: And Calculated according to 20 Leagues for a Degree.
LONDON, Printed by W. Godbid for G. Hurlock, over against St. Magnus Church, on London-Bridge, near Thames-Street, and W. Fisher at the Postern-Gate near Great Tower-hill. 1669.

DIV1.HEAD: THE FIRST PART: CONTAINING All the Distances and Thwart Courses of the Eastern and Northern Navigation, Contained in the New and much Enlarged SEA-MIRROUR.

From the North end of Silt, called List, to the South end of Rim, or Rem, is N E and S W one mile. Rem is two miles and an half long, and stretcheth almost South and North.

DIV1.HEAD: Advertisement to the Reader.
DIV1.P: VVHereas in the Translation of the Dutch Sea-Mirrour, and the Lighting Column, many gross Errors have been committed in the Distances and Courses, as also Dutch Miles placed for and in the name and title of English Leagues, The Reader may please to take notice that the faults are corrected, and the Dutch Miles calculated, and turned into English Leagues, as they ought to be, according to 20 Leagues in a Degree, for the good and right understanding of our English Navi∣gators and Sea-men; and for preventing all difficulties and mistakes which otherwise easily might happen. By a Well-wisher of the good and welfare of our English Nation, hoping it will take as kind acceptance by all Lovers of this Famous Art, as willingness in the Translator.

DIV2.HEAD: Instructions for the fore-going Tide-Tables.
DIV2.P: THe Practitioner is to take notice that the three Columns of Fi∣gures belonging to each point of the Compass, are Days, Hours, and Minutes of and after the New or Full Moon. As for Example:

I desire to know when the Moon is 7 days past the New or Full when she comes to the South South West, or makes High-water be∣fore Yarmouth, the Rivers mouth of London, and the Downs on the Road, &c. And as in this, so in all other places, I seek in the several points, till I find the said places, and there I see that they stand under the South South West, and North North East point, therefore in the Columne of Dayes I find 7, and next to it I see 7 hours 6 minutes; Upon that Day then the Moon shall come to the South South West, and North North East, and upon those places mentioned, under that point make High-water.

Nota, that the Tides do not hold out, but fall short 48 minutes, which is four fifths of an hour. Therefore if you know at what hour, the New or Full Moon make full Sea in any place, then reckon from that time every day four fifths of an hour later, and so find the right time of the High-water.
